block.p: International 2-5

An Austrian jet crashed in Thailand. Thai officials at the crash site said that all 223 people aboard the airliner, bound from Bangkok to Vienna, were believed dead. The cause of the crash remained a mystery. Page 1
International 2-5

An Austrian jet crashed in Thailand. Thai officials at the crash site said that all 223 people aboard the airliner, bound from Bangkok to Vienna, were believed dead. The cause of the crash remained a mystery. Page 1

Ethiopian rebels seized an air base that served as the headquarters of the air force. American diplomats asked rebel representatives in London to halt the offensive and enter talks to form a new Government. 1
In Ethiopia's besieged capital: tenderness, fear, anger 5
Hundreds of Israelis volunteer to help the Ethiopian Jews 5

Nigeria's transition to democracy, promised by Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, has been a qualified success. Though he has choreographed the process, the first election was a real political contest free of violence. 1

Another suspect in the assassination of Rajiv Gandhi has emerged. The photograph of a woman who set off a bomb strapped to her body had been cropped to exclude a man who the authorities say accompanied her. 3

Half of Egypt's $20.2 billion debt has been forgiven by the United States and its allies, partly to thank Cairo for its support during the gulf war. The Bush Administration had lobbied hard for the debt relief. 1

American soldiers in northern Iraq are forbidden to give candy to Kurdish children, because custom dictates that if you receive a gift, you must give one back, and some of the children chose to give live munitions. 3

The victors in Suriname's election, two groups favoring stronger ties with the Netherlands and subordination of the military, emerged with more than the legislative majority needed to undertake change. 4
Brasilia Journal: Where the "sound-bite" is a T-shirt 2
Colombia passes Brazil in the world's coffee business 33 National 6-9

A plan to raise college tuition grants for the poor and eliminate them for students whose families earn more than $10,000 a year is very likely to touch off a battle between the Bush Administration and Congress. 1

Reporter's Notebook: The President has begun a five-day Memorial Day vacation seemingly determined to defy the hyperactive thyroid that had prompted his doctors to ask him to slow down just a little. 6

A number of plans for reducing taxes have been floated, but despite the search for a campaign issue, the plans have little chance of passing because of the need for revenue and the opposition of Dan Rostenkowski. 33

Banks are now compiling "scores" for each customer in the credit card business. Using computers to devour bits of data, banks are learning to avoid risks, provide better service and collect on delinquent loans. 33

The national parks are facing threats from within and without. As it celebrates its 75th anniversary, the National Park Service is questioning its basic mission: Is it running theme parks or natural sanctuaries? 1
Washington Talk: Italy's envoy reshaped old image in new era 7

The job is not over for the Reserves. Most of the active duty forces that served in the Persian Gulf are home but a disproportionate number of reservists are still there or on active duty in the United States. 6
A Hispanic woman is defeated in San Antonio's mayoral race 6

Tougher laws on acquaintance rape have made prosecutors more willing to bring charges in cases in which women have been attacked by someone they know. But the issue still presents difficult legal challenges. 8
Suspects recount a Halloween night of murder in Boston 6 Regional 21-24

New York City's business community is increasingly concerned about the city's fiscal future and the prospect of higher taxes. After giving Mayor Dinkins a honeymoon, business leaders are challenging his policies. 1
Metro Matters: With new power, Council finds new scrutiny 22

A break in Albany's budget impasse may be near. Governor Cuomo said he may urge the Legislature to pass its own version of a budget, parts of which he would veto, rather than insisting on a version he approved. 21
The Coast Guard takes new steps to halt drunken boating 23

A civilian patrol group has been sued for calling itself the Pink Panthers. The company that owns the rights to the "Pink Panther" movies says the group, formed to protect homosexuals, infringes on its trademark. 21

An 8-year-old missing in Manhattan reunited with mother 23 A driver in automobile accident fired into a crowd of bystanders in Manhattan after one of them complained that the car was blocking traffic. Two men were killed and three were critically injured in the shooting. 23
Girl playing in front of her Bronx building caught in gunfire 23

Jewish children who were hidden by non-Jewish friends or strangers after their parents were killed, deported or forced to flee from the Nazis gathered at a Manhattan hotel, searching for some of what they had lost. 21

The Bronx High School of Science brought them together, and World War II drove them apart. After 50 years, members of the first graduating class at what was then a radical experiment were reunited. 23
Theater Row Journal: A shot at making it -- near Broadway 23

New Jersey's teachers are under fire from politicians who say they are overpaid. Some critics have begun to suggest that the state's effort to improve education has succeeded, mainly, in raising salaries. 21 Business Digest D1 Sports 25-32
Auto Racing: Mears wins Indy 500 for fourth time 25
Baseball: Mets bombed, 14-4 25

Kieran E. O'Doherty, a founder of New York's Conservative Party
Jacob Clayman, former lobbyist and A.F.L.-C.I.O. official Arts/Entertainment

A dramatic spectacle at Ellis Island -- called "Immigrant Voices" -- will mix the words of immigrants into a production that is part docudrama and part musical. Shows will be held on June 10 and 11. 11

Senator William Cohen's new thriller is "One-Eye Kings." The novel includes an assassinated senator, a Mossad agent, sexual liaisons and intrigue -- set in a world the Republican from Maine knows well. 11
Sculpture at Spoleto Festival 11
Seeking ballet talent in public schools 11
